query: Does the application/framework use content delivery networks (CDNs) to minimize recomputation or fetching of static data?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.
response_text:
Response: No
Explanation: The context provided focuses on configuring Traffic Server and an origin service with a different port mapping, without any mention of using CDNs. Hence, the application does not use content delivery networks (CDNs) as per this design document snippet for minimizing recomputation or fetching static data in real-time scenarios like online games.

query: Does the application/framework implement edge caching strategies to reduce static data retrieval times?
context_text:
You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.
response_text:
Judgement: Yes
Explanation: The context discusses using cache sizes and proxy configuration, which implies implementing a form of content delivery network or localized caches as part of an edge computing strategy. However, explicit mention of CDNs is not made in the text provided. Nevertheless, since Traffic Server can handle static HTTP requests to reduce retrieval times locally instead of fetching from origin on every request, it demonstrates a similar principle behind using content delivery networks for caching purposes at the application/framework level.

In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

query: Does the application/framework utilize geo-IP routing to direct users to the nearest server location?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

proxy.config.http.server_ports
This configures Traffic Server to bind itself to the port 8080 for HTTP traffic, for both IPv4 and IPv6.

Configure Origin Location¶
The previous settings enable reverse proxying (and prevent flagrant abuse of it), but now Traffic Server needs to know what to proxy. This is achieved by writing remap rules, which make use of the core Configuration Remap Plugin. For our Getting Started guide’s Acme Widgets example scenario, we have very simple needs and want little more than to proxy all requests to our single origin server. This is accomplished with the following rule added to the remap.config configuration:

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

This is achieved by writing remap rules, which make use of the core Configuration Remap Plugin. For our Getting Started guide’s Acme Widgets example scenario, we have very simple needs and want little more than to proxy all requests to our single origin server. query: Does the application/framework employ gzip compression to reduce storage requirements and bandwidth?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.
response_text:
Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The context provided discusses using a Content Delivery Network (CDN) through Traffic Server for caching purposes, but it does not mention anything about gzip compression. Gzip compression is another technique often used to reduce data size during transmission and storage requirements, distinct from CDN usage in cache static data.

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

query: Does the application/framework deploy workloads in Docker containers to optimize resource allocation?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.
response_text:
Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The provided context does not mention anything about using Docker containers for deployment or optimizing resource allocation, as it primarily discusses setting up a transparent proxy with Traffic Server and configuring reverse proxy rules.

query: Does the application/framework use Kubernetes for orchestrating containers to ensure efficient scaling and management of resources?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context provided discusses Traffic Server configurations related to HTTP(S) proxying, SSL termination, and domain mappings. There is no mention of using Kubernetes or container orchestration for resource management in the given text.

context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.
response_text:
Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The context provided discusses Traffic Server and proxy caching for performance improvement but does not mention or imply any use of a microservices architecture. query: Does the application/framework automatically delete unattached volumes to conserve storage space?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.', metadata={'id': 'documentsFromText/TrafficServer/content.txt:None:22', 'source': 'documentsFromText/TrafficServer/content.txt'}), 1747.483760873667)]

query: Does the application/framework apply encryption selectively to only sensitive data to optimize energy usage?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context does not mention any form of encrypted communication being used in this configuration, nor discusses optimization for energy usage through selective encryption. It primarily focuses on network routing and proxy configurations without specific reference to security practices like SSL/TLS or data sensitivity considerations regarding resource allocation.

your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context provided focuses on Traffic Server configurations for caching and improving website performance but does not mention any implementation of conditional access policies or their role in reducing cryptographic overhead. Therefore, based on this excerpt, there is no indication that the application/framework uses such technologies to minimize unnecessary encryption.

query: Does the application/framework evaluate the necessity of implementing a service mesh to prevent unnecessary overhead?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.
response_text:
Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The context provided does not mention or discuss any considerations regarding whether an implementation is necessary for using a Service Mesh, making it inapplicable. It only focuses on deploying Traffic Server and related configurations within the same host environment to improve website performance and internet access efficiency at Acme Widgets' office.

query: Does the application/framework use lightweight service mesh alternatives when simpler solutions can suffice?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context does not mention any usage of lightweight service meshes or suggest that they are being used as an alternative to simpler solutions; it primarily discusses caching and TLS termination.

query: Does the application/framework terminate TLS connections at the border gateway to minimize internal network encryption overhead?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context discusses how Acme Widgets may handle HTTPS requests by translating them into HTTP internally and forwarding traffic through a proxy on their own host. It does not mention terminating TLS connections at the border gateway to minimize internal network encryption overhead; instead, it talks about handling SSL inbound/outbound communication within Traffic Server configurations.

query: Does the application/framework utilize stateless protocols to ensure scalability across multiple servers?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context provided discusses Traffic Server's proxying capabilities, caching strategies for website performance improvement, and office internet access concerns; it does not mention anything about using stateless protocols within the application framework. Stateless protocol design principles are crucial in some architectures but were not applicable to this specific setup as described by focusing on Traffic Server's proxying role.

Example Scenario¶

cd /opt/ts
sudo bin/traffic_server -R 1
Configuration¶
We will be tackling two separate configuration scenarios in the following sections. The first is the most common application of a performance-enhancing caching proxy for externally-facing websites, a transparent and caching reverse proxy which forwards all requests presented to it to a single origin address and caches the responses based on their cache control headers (as well as some simple heuristics for specific content types when cache control headers are not present).

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. ---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

---

proxy.config.http.server_ports
This configures Traffic Server to bind itself to the port 8080 for HTTP traffic, for both IPv4 and IPv6.

Configure Origin Location¶
The previous settings enable reverse proxying (and prevent flagrant abuse of it), but now Traffic Server needs to know what to proxy. This is achieved by writing remap rules, which make use of the core Configuration Remap Plugin. For our Getting Started guide’s Acme Widgets example scenario, we have very simple needs and want little more than to proxy all requests to our single origin server. This is accomplished with the following rule added to the remap.config configuration:

context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context provided focuses on setting up Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer and does not discuss creating specific Service Level Objectives (SLOs) based on business needs. It mainly deals with performance optimization rather than aligning SLOs to the company's requirements.

The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

query: Does the application/framework use auto-scaling features to dynamically adjust VM capacities based on real-time demand?
context_text:
You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context provided does not mention any auto-scaling capabilities or VM capacity management, which are specific technologies for managing dynamic resource allocation. It focuses instead on Traffic Server configurations and caching strategies. Auto-scaling typically relates to cloud infrastructures rather than content delivery networks (CDNs) or direct application features as described in the context provided.

query: Is the application/framework utilizing predictive analytics to forecast and right-size VM allocations according to anticipated workload changes?
context_text:
You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

---

Example Scenario¶

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

cd /opt/ts
sudo bin/traffic_server -R 1
Configuration¶
We will be tackling two separate configuration scenarios in the following sections. The first is the most common application of a performance-enhancing caching proxy for externally-facing websites, a transparent and caching reverse proxy which forwards all requests presented to it to a single origin address and caches the responses based on their cache control headers (as well as some simple heuristics for specific content types when cache control headers are not present).

Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

query: Does the application/framework define and enforce storage retention policies to automatically delete old or unused data?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.
response_text:
Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The provided context does not mention anything about defining or enforcing storage retention policies for automatic deletion of old or unused data. It discusses other aspects like reverse and forward proxies, caching configuration, transparent proxying, network routing, and monitoring security but nothing related to the mentioned green practice.

query: Does the application/framework implement traffic management policies to prioritize critical traffic over lower priority traffic?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

cd /opt/ts
sudo bin/traffic_server -R 1
Configuration¶
We will be tackling two separate configuration scenarios in the following sections. The first is the most common application of a performance-enhancing caching proxy for externally-facing websites, a transparent and caching reverse proxy which forwards all requests presented to it to a single origin address and caches the responses based on their cache control headers (as well as some simple heuristics for specific content types when cache control headers are not present).
response_text:

The context focuses instead on caching strategies using Host headers, performance improvement through Traffic Server's configuration in both scenarios—improving the website speed of Acme Widgets as well as enhancing internal office network access without prioritizing traffic types by importance or criticality.

query: Does the application/framework use quality of service (QoS) mechanisms to ensure critical traffic is prioritized and lower priority traffic is limited during peak times?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The context provided discusses Traffic Server configuration for caching proxy, domain mapping rules, HTTPS termination setup, but does not mention anything about Quality of Service (QoS) mechanisms. QoS typically pertains to managing bandwidth and prioritizing traffic in network environments rather than within a software framework's design document context. Thus it is not applicable here.

Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

query: Does the application/framework schedule Kubernetes cron jobs during off-peak hours to reduce resource contention?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context provided does not mention anything about scheduling Kubernetes cron jobs or any time-based operations related to minimizing resource contention. It discusses traffic routing, proxying configurations, and SSL termination but makes no reference to the use of scheduled tasks within a cloud orchestration system like Kubernetes.

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/

your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

context_text:
You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/

response_text:

query: Is the application/framework configured to log and analyze circuit breaker events to identify and resolve underlying issues promptly?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.
response_text:
Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The provided context does not mention anything about logging, analyzing, or monitoring Circuit Breaker Events in Traffic Server. It mainly discusses mapping domains for requests, setting up HTTPS with SSL certificates, and configuring caching proxies to improve website performance and office Internet access efficiency.

query: Does the application/framework implement DDoS protection services provided by the cloud provider to safeguard against attacks?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context does not mention anything about implementing or using Distributed Denial of Service (DDoS) protection services, which are typically offered as a feature by many cloud providers. Instead, it focuses on caching proxy layers and SSL termination for security purposes.

query: Does the application/framework utilize rate limiting and traffic filtering techniques to mitigate potential DDoS attacks?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.
response_text:
Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The context provided does not mention anything about using rate limiting or employing traffic filters for protection against DDoS attacks. It focuses on the setup of Traffic Server, caching strategies, and configuration changes to port numbers. There is no explicit detail regarding mitigating techniques that would counteract potential DDoS threats in this particular context.

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.
response_text:
Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The context provided discusses caching and proxy servers but does not mention anything about using cloud-native processor VMs. Therefore, it is not applicable based on this design document excerpt.

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context given focuses on Traffic Server configurations for caching content at a specific domain and securing HTTPS traffic. There is no mention or indication of features related to cloud-native VMs like enhanced networking, optimized storage, or automatic scaling in the provided text.
