query: Does the application/framework adopt serverless cloud services like AWS Lambda, Azure Functions, or Google Cloud Functions to optimize resource usage?
context_text:
You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context provided discusses Traffic Server configurations and proxy settings within a network environment but does not mention anything about using serverless architectures such as AWS Lambda, Azure Functions, or Google Cloud Functions. These services are unrelated to the content of the given text which is focused on traffic management rather than cloud computing models for resource optimization.

query: Is the application/framework configured to automatically shut down and clean up inactive environments to conserve resources?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context provided does not mention any configuration related to automatic shutdown or resource conservation upon detecting an inactive environment. It mainly discusses Traffic Server configurations, cache settings, monitoring, security aspects, etc., but nothing about automatically managing and conserving resources for idle environments is mentioned.

query: Does the application/framework utilize a single production environment to reduce resource usage?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.
response_text:
Judgement: Yes
Explanation: The context implies that Traffic Server and the origin service are deployed on the same host after configuration changes were made for them both, suggesting a single production environment. This consolidates resources as there is no mention of multiple environments or separate setups required by either component; they share physical hardware (the "same host").

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context does not provide specific details on whether the software deployment strategy includes or excludes using multiple redundant development environments to support a green practice, hence we cannot determine its presence.

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

query: Does the application/framework archive infrequently accessed data to less energy-intensive storage solutions?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

query: Does the application/framework implement load balancing to distribute workloads evenly across servers?
context_text:
You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context provided does not mention anything related to load balancing or distributing workloads across servers; it discusses domain mapping, transparent proxying configurations and SSL termination.

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/

Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

query: Does the application/framework ensure compatibility with power-saving modes on end-user devices?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.
response_text:
Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The context provided does not discuss or imply anything about ensuring compatibility with power-saving modes on end-user devices, which is typically related to web design and development rather than caching proxies.

query: Does the application/framework implement request throttling to manage peak CPU usage?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context provided does not mention any specific technologies or techniques implemented for managing traffic load, such as using a queue system with timeout management like Traffic Server's default configuration. query: Does the application/framework prioritize critical tasks over non-urgent ones to manage peak loads?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context provided focuses on caching strategies and proxy configurations for performance improvements but does not mention any mechanisms or policies related to task prioritization. query: Does the application/framework schedule non-urgent processing during off-peak hours to reduce peak loads?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.
response_text:
Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The provided context discusses technical details about Traffic Server configuration, domain mapping for HTTP and SSL termination but does not mention anything related to load scheduling or handling of non-urgent processing during off-peak hours. Therefore the application/framework in this case is not applicable regarding green practices such as reducing peak loads by shifting certain tasks outside high traffic periods.

your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

query: Does the application/framework use tools to identify and clean up unused code and libraries?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context does not mention anything related to identifying or removing unused code or libraries, which are activities typically associated with maintaining software efficiency rather than using a specific technology.

query: Does the application/framework use Kubernetes auto-scaling to reduce resource usage during idle periods?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.
response_text:

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/

Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context provided does not mention anything related to using serverless functions, nor does it discuss scaling based on usage within Traffic Server configurations or design. It focuses primarily on proxy caching and TLS termination settings for Acme Widgets' deployment scenario.

query: Does the application/framework employ resource allocation policies to minimize resources for idle applications?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.
response_text:

Explanation: The context provided does not mention anything about an application's behavior when it is idle or any specific resource allocation policies related to idleness. It discusses aspects of proxying, security, and cache configuration but nothing that directly answers the question asked regarding minimizing resources for idle applications.

context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context does not mention anything about using auto-scaling groups, which is a service designed to automatically scale resources in response to load. Instead, it discusses proxy caching and port reconfiguration for Traffic Server and the origin server within an example scenario involving Acme Widgets' website performance improvements.

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

query: Does the application/framework implement a continuous integration pipeline that includes security checks?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.
response_text:
Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The context provided discusses Traffic Server configurations for caching web content and improving site performance but does not mention anything about a continuous integration pipeline or its features, including security checks. Therefore, the answer is "Not Applicable."

Example Scenario¶

proxy.config.http.server_ports
This configures Traffic Server to bind itself to the port 8080 for HTTP traffic, for both IPv4 and IPv6.

Configure Origin Location¶
The previous settings enable reverse proxying (and prevent flagrant abuse of it), but now Traffic Server needs to know what to proxy. This is achieved by writing remap rules, which make use of the core Configuration Remap Plugin. For our Getting Started guide’s Acme Widgets example scenario, we have very simple needs and want little more than to proxy all requests to our single origin server. This is accomplished with the following rule added to the remap.config configuration:

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

query: Does the application/framework employ traffic shaping techniques to manage lower priority traffic during peak times?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.
response_text:
Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The provided context does not mention any specifics about managing different priorities of incoming requests or implementing load balancing strategies such as Traffic Server's prerouting, which can be used to implement a form of traffic shaping. It only discusses the redirection and proxy mechanisms but lacks information on handling varying request loads effectively during peak times.

query: Does the application/framework schedule Kubernetes cron jobs during off-peak hours to reduce peak load?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

query: Does the application/framework leverage cloud-native access control mechanisms to secure network resources?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context provided discusses proxy configurations and routing without any mention of using cloud-native access control mechanisms for securing network resources.

query: Does the application/framework implement DDoS protection services to maintain service availability during attacks?
context_text:
You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The context provided does not mention any implementation of DDoS protection services within the Traffic Server setup for Acme Widgets' applications or internet access. It focuses on caching and secure HTTP protocol translation instead.

query: Does the application/framework leverage serverless architectures to reduce idle resource consumption?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.
response_text:
Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The context discusses using Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer and leveraging it in different scenarios, but there is no mention of utilizing serverless architecture within this setup. Therefore, the application/framework does not leverage serverless architectures based on the given information.

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. cd /opt/ts
sudo bin/traffic_server -R 1
Configuration¶
We will be tackling two separate configuration scenarios in the following sections. The first is the most common application of a performance-enhancing caching proxy for externally-facing websites, a transparent and caching reverse proxy which forwards all requests presented to it to a single origin address and caches the responses based on their cache control headers (as well as some simple heuristics for specific content types when cache control headers are not present).

query: Does the application/framework use efficient neural network architectures (like MobileNet, SqueezeNet) to reduce the size of AI models and save storage space?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

Judgement: Not Applicable
Explanation: The context provided discusses Traffic Server configurations for caching web pages but does not mention anything about using specific AI model architectures or saving storage space. Therefore, it is not applicable to this question regarding neural network efficiencies in software development within the given text snippet.

query: Does the application/framework deploy AI models on edge devices to reduce energy consumption?
context_text:
Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

---

your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

Therefore, the judgement is 'Not Applicable'.

your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

Therefore, based on this specific design document excerpt, we can conclude that the application/framework described here is not using edge computing in this way.

query: Does the application/framework use AI/ML frameworks built on energy-efficient programming languages like C or C++?
context_text:
your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

---

You may also want to learn more about Monitoring, or ensuring that your installation is properly secured by reading the Security section. Properly sizing your cache, both the on-disk cache and the companion memory cache, are important topics covered in Proxy Cache Configuration.

---

In our Acme Widgets scenario, they ultimately decide to deploy Traffic Server at which point, since they are running both Traffic Server and their origin web server on the same host, they reconfigure their origin service to listen on port 8080 instead of the default, and change Traffic Server to bind to 80 itself. Updating the remap is thus required, and it should now be:

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
Now all requests made to www.acme.com are received by Traffic Server which knows to proxy those requests to localhost:8080 if it cannot already serve them from its cache. Because we enabled pristine host headers earlier, the origin service will continue to receive Host: www.acme.com in the HTTP request.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

context_text:
Transparent Proxy
A transparent proxy may be either a reverse or forward proxy (though nearly all reverse proxies are deployed transparently), the defining feature being the use of network routing to send requests through the proxy without any need for clients to configure themselves to do so, and often without the ability for those clients to bypass the proxy.

For a more complete list of definitions, please see the Glossary.

your origin service and Traffic Server on the same host) and should no longer receive requests sent to the primary domain on its default ports.

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.

---

Finally, if Acme Widgets decides to secure their site with https, they will need two additional remap rules to handle the https requests. Traffic Server can translate an inbound https request to an http request to origin. So, they would have additional remap rules like:

map https://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:8080/
map https://static.acme.com/ https://origin-static.acme.com/
This will require installing a certificate, and adding a line to ssl_multicert.config. Assuming the cert has the static.acme.com alternate name, and that cert should be presented by default:

dest_ip=* ssl_cert_name=/path/to/secret/privatekey/acme.rsa
Further information about configuring Traffic Server for TLS can be found Basic SSL Termination section of the documentation.
response_text:
Judgement: No
Explanation: The provided context discusses software development concepts and configurations, including transparent proxies and Traffic Server usage, but does not mention anything related to machine learning frameworks like PyTorch or specific technologies optimized for low-power consumption.

---

Example Scenario¶
In this guide, we will use the fictional company Acme Widgets as a basis for the configuration examples. Acme Widgets has a product brochure website (assumed to reside at the domain www.acme.com) that performs very poorly. The content management software they chose takes an unbearable amount of time to generate pages on every request and their engineering team has chosen Traffic Server as a caching proxy layer to improve site performance.

Separately, Acme Widgets has decided to use Traffic Server to help improve the performance of their office’s Internet access, which is hobbled by their reliance on an aging leased line and certain employees’ predilection for extracurricular web browsing.

---

map http://www.acme.com/ http://localhost:80/
With this mapping rule, all paths that Traffic Server receives with a Host: header of www.acme.com will be proxied to localhost:80. For instance, a request for http://www.acme.com/foo/bar will be proxied to http://localhost:80/foo/bar, while requests with other Host: headers will be rejected.

---

With transparent proxying, clients require no configuration and may be given no option to bypass the proxy. This configuration requires your network to route all requests automatically to the proxy. The details of how to accomplish this routing are entirely dependent upon the layout of your network and the routing devices you use.

For a more detailed discussion of the options, and starting points for configuring each in your network environment, please refer to the Forward Proxy section of the Administrator’s Guide.
